review.title: Personalized Emphasis Framing for Persuasive Message Generation
review.abstract: In this paper, we present a study on personalized emphasis framing which can be used to tailor the content of a message to enhance its appeal to different individuals. With this framework, we directly model content selection decisions based on a set of psychologically-motivated domain-independent personal traits including personality (e.g., extraversion and conscientiousness) and basic human values (e.g., self-transcendence and hedonism). We also demonstrate how the analysis results can be used in automated personalized content selection for persuasive message generation.

sections.text: Below we summarize the most relevant research findings for our work, including previous psychology and communication studies linking stress formation to personal traits. As the construction of computer models for stress formation was not the primary goal of these studies, we also include literature on the personalized generation of natural language.

sections.heading: 2.2 Personalized NLG
sections.text: For example, STOP is a Natural Language Generation (NLG) system that creates customized smoking cessation letters based on responses to a four-page smoking questionnaire (Reiter et al., 2003); PERSIVAL customizes the content of search summaries based on their relevance to a patient's health situation (McKeown et al., 2003); MATCH is a multimodal dialogue system that tailors the content of its responses based on a user's restaurant preferences; M-PIRO tailors the words and complexity of museum object descriptions to different audiences (e.g. adults, children and experts); PERSONAGE (Biewen and Weiser, 2011) and CRAG 2 (Gill et al., 2012) adapt different linguistic styles to project the intended personality in spoken expressions.

sections.heading: 3 Acquiring Personal Traits
sections.text: Since previous studies often link framing effects to individual traits such as personality and individual motivations and beliefs, we focus here on two widely accepted characteristic models in psychology: the Big5 personality model (Goldberg, 1993) and Schwartz "basic human value model (Schwartz, 2003). Figure 1 shows the description of each of the Big5 personality traits along with each of the five basic human value traits. Traditionally, psychometric tests have been used to determine a person's personality and value traits, such as the IPIP test for the personality of the Big 5 (Yarkoni, 2010a) and the PVQ survey for values (Schwartz, 2003). Recent research in the field of psycholinguistics has shown that it is possible to automatically deduce personal traits from one's own linguistic footprint, such as tweets, Facebook posts and blogs (Yarkoni, 2010b; Celli and Polonio, 2014).

sections.heading: 5 Learning Emphasis Framing Strategies
sections.text: The aim of this study is to derive patterns of emphasis based on the characteristics of a recipient and his or her choice of aspects.

sections.heading: 5.1 Data Collection
sections.text: In Task 3, each Turk was asked to complete the IPIP and PVQ surveys in order to obtain their Big5 personality and value ratings, and we also asked them to rate all eight aspects of the car based on their importance to them. In order to control the influence of the value of a car aspect on the user's choice of aspect (for example, if the value of "safety" is "bad" and the value of "fuel economy" is "good," the car is almost always described as "a car with good fuel economy," not "an unsafe car," regardless of the recipient's personality).In this study, we did not specify the values of all aspects of the car. After removing the invalid data, our data set shows 594 valid answers, each containing the personality and value of a Turk as well as his rank of the eight aspects of the car. In the following, we describe how we analyze the relationship between that aspect and his rank.

sections.heading: 5.3 Pattern Discovery with Constrained Clustering
sections.text: In regression analysis, we considered only the most important effects. In order to detect high-level interaction patterns with limited data, we cannot use clustering of group people with similar traits in common. Furthermore, we also want to encourage people within a cluster to share similar aspect preferences. Otherwise, we will not be able to link the trait patterns discovered in a cluster with aspect preferences. To facilitate this analysis, we first classified the aspect of the order obtained in Task 3 into discrete categories. For a complete ranking of eight auto aspects, we have the three ranked aspects into an "importer" class, bottom three into a "non-importer" class, and the middle two into a "neutral" class. sections.heading: 6 Apply Emphasis Framing in NLG
sections.text: "The patterns derived in the previous section can be used in the personalized content selection for natural language generation." Generally, to promote a car, people tend to highlight the good aspects and avoid the bad aspects, regardless of the recipient's personality. For example, people will highlight the aspect of fuel efficiency when a car is very fuel efficient, while de-marking the same aspect when a car is not fuel efficient. Thus, during content selection, the values of all aspects are taken into account to take into account the value of an aspect, we will use a cascade aspect of the NLG model that includes aspects of value-oriented content selection: (1) the values of all aspects whose trait scores of a given recipient are taken into account; (3) the eight linear regression models that we have learned in section 5.2, one for each aspect; (4) the rules of interaction that we have learned in section 5.3; (5) the number of values that is determined by the values that are needed in the output; (6) the number of aspects that are determined by the values that vary.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion: Domain Generalization
sections.text: In general, there are two major challenges in adapting a domain-trained personalized content selection model to another domain: (1) adapting the data model from one domain (e.g., restaurant data) to another domain (e.g., movie data); (2) adapting a domain-specific user model (e.g., the preferences of a user of restaurant functions such as "cooking") to another domain (e.g., the preferences of a user of movie functions such as "movie genre"). Although our current model is trained in the automotive field, we have introduced a domain-independent user model motivated by psychological theories (e.g., personality and basic human values) rather than using domain-based user preference models (e.g., the preferences of a user of "fuel economy"), which has made our work much more generalizable than systems that can apply domain-based user characteristics (e.g., basic personality and general human outcomes) to adeira.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: In this study, we analyzed the relationship between an individual's characteristics and his / her perceived aspect meaning. Our analysis revealed interesting patterns that can be used to automatically adjust the content of a message to increase its appeal to an individual. We also proposed a cascade selection model to automatically incorporate the analysis results into automated, compelling message generation, and our evaluation results demonstrated the effectiveness of this approach.
